ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Some stuff about circuits? Honestly, I wouldn't know. I'm disillusioned with the EE major in general. Should've done CS, probably would've made more money and have an actual useful degree.
Analog analysis of transistor circuits (MOS and BJT), multistage/operational amplifier design and analysis

I learned advanced analog circuit analysis, including the design of transistor amplifier circuits and the basics of semiconductor device physics. This course is where all the circuit analysis skills and knowledge from previous courses like EENG 200 and EENG 203 get pulled together and you learn how to design more advanced circuit configurations. This class is more about properties of circuits (amplification, input resistance, output resistance, etc.) rather than properties of circuit components (impedance of capacitors, frequency response of capacitors, etc.).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Gosh. Where do I start? First, it does not help when the professor assumes that we are understanding what he is talking about. Like, no one is understanding, don't erase the board. Second, this course was just poorly taught. You can't just cram an entire semester of content into 5 lectures. It would be nice to have a more steady increase in difficulty throughout the course rather than just throwing us down the cliff.
Got a little overwhelming at certain points.
Xia is a very clear lecturer and the course is generally pretty well-planned with fair exams and homeworks.

Strengths: course material is very logical. Each lecture builds on the previous lecture's content, and by the end I felt pretty confident when analyzing analog circuits. 
Weaknesses: The labs feel somewhat disconnected from lecture material. I found myself being able to complete the labs simply by following the instructions, but not really coming away with a greater understanding of how the circuits functioned.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: NO ABSOLUTELY NOT. EE ISN'T WORTH IT. As someone who has been through hell in EE, I say from the bottom of my heart - go major in something else. EE is not worth it.
Only if it is required for your major. As an EECS, if you would like to focus more on EE I could see it as a possibility.
Not unless you have to for the major, or are really interested in transistor amplifiers for some reason
I think this course is better taught than EENG 200, and it is a fine course, you can understand circuits pretty well.

People typically only take this course if it's required, but I would still recommend this course. This course is great at showing how all the basic circuit analysis ideas in EENG 200/203 tie together; I think it makes circuit analysis more interesting because you finally see abstract ideas being applied to achieve something concrete.
